metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: Cosmic-ray observation system of soil moisture of Daman Superstation, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a Cosmic-ray Soil Moisture Observing System of soil moisture of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, C), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour), thermal neutron counts (N2C, counts per hour), sample time of fast neutrons (N1ET, s), and sample time of thermal neutrons (N2ET, s). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main criteria used for data screening in the collection of cosmic ray data in arid regions?
Concept Completion.Answer: voltage less than or equal to 11.8 volts, relative humidity greater than or equal to 80%, sampling intervals not within 60±1 minutes, fast neutron counts vary by more than 200 compared to the previous or subsequent hour

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: One example is the use of cosmic ray neutron sensing at a superstation site, where the data is collected by measuring fast and thermal neutron counts, which are then calibrated to determine soil moisture content. This method involves data screening, pressure correction, and instrument calibration steps to ensure accuracy.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting long-term hydrometeorological data in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is the degradation of the ecological environment, such as drying rivers and increased land desertification, which can complicate the maintenance and accuracy of long-term data collection from automatic weather stations in arid regions.

Definition.Question: What is the definition of a 'superstation' in the context of land surface flux and meteorological observations?
Definition.Answer: A 'superstation' refers to a comprehensive observation site within a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations that typically includes a wide array of instruments and sensors to measure various environmental parameters. In the context provided, it is a part of a network of 11 stations in the Heihe River Basin, which includes 2 superstations for detailed and extensive data collection.

Definition.Question: What does 'cosmic ray observation system' mean in the context of environmental monitoring?
Definition.Answer: A 'cosmic ray observation system' in environmental monitoring refers to an instrument setup used to measure cosmic ray neutrons to infer environmental variables such as soil moisture. In the context provided, the system at a superstation measures parameters like voltage, temperature, relative humidity, pressure, and neutron counts, which are used to derive soil volumetric water content.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'pressure correction' in the analysis of cosmic ray neutron data?
Definition.Answer: 'Pressure correction' in the analysis of cosmic ray neutron data refers to the adjustment of neutron counts to account for atmospheric pressure variations. This correction is essential because changes in pressure affect the neutron count readings. The pressure-corrected neutron counts provide more accurate data for calculating soil moisture, as described in the data processing methods of the cosmic ray observation system.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing and quality control procedures between a dataset involving cosmic ray neutron data and another involving hydrometeorological data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: The data processing for cosmic ray neutron datasets involves specific steps such as voltage and humidity data filtering, pressure correction, and calibration for soil moisture calculation. In contrast, datasets from oasis–desert systems use a broader range of data, including energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and hydrometeorological observations, requiring different quality control measures like data collection, processing, and archiving, emphasizing the integration of various environmental parameters.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are inherent in collecting high-frequency neutron and meteorological data in oasis-desert ecosystems, and how might these affect data interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include environmental degradation factors like drying rivers and desertification, which can impact data accuracy. Additionally, instrument sensitivity to voltage, humidity, and time intervals can lead to data exclusion, potentially affecting interpretations of oasis-desert interactions and the ecological stability of these areas.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes enhance the understanding of oasis–desert ecosystem interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term datasets provide comprehensive insights into the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These datasets, obtained through techniques like eddy covariance and scintillometer measurements, help quantify the balance of these elements, informing sustainable development and ecological security strategies for maintaining oasis–desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for pressure correction in the data collected by cosmic ray instruments in agricultural fields?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Pressure correction is needed due to the influence of atmospheric pressure on the measurement of fast neutrons by cosmic ray instruments. The correction ensures that the neutron count is accurate and reflects the actual environmental conditions, compensating for variations caused by changes in pressure.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the challenges faced in maintaining ecological stability in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in maintaining ecological stability in oasis-desert systems are primarily due to environmental degradation, such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are exacerbated by the fragile ecological balance in arid regions and the critical role of oases in supporting the local population and economy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of applying rigorous data screening criteria on the reliability and usability of data collected from oasis–desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying rigorous data screening criteria, such as those used in the cosmic ray observation system, can enhance the reliability of the dataset by ensuring that only high-quality data are retained. This can lead to more accurate interpretations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert areas, thereby improving the understanding of ecological stability and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of long-term observational datasets impact the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of long-term observational datasets allows for a comprehensive understanding of the dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems. These datasets provide essential insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, supporting ecological security and sustainable development goals in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a comprehensive dataset for observing cosmic rays in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a comprehensive dataset for observing cosmic rays in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin is crucial for understanding the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This knowledge supports the ecological security and sustainable development of these areas, which are vital for the local population and environment.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of implementing stringent data processing and quality control measures in the collection of hydrometeorological data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing stringent data processing and quality control measures in the collection of hydrometeorological data is significant to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data. This is essential for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is necessary to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems and achieve sustainable development goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why focus on obtaining long-term observational data in artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Focusing on obtaining long-term observational data in artificial and natural oasis–desert systems is important to capture the dynamic interactions and changes in these ecosystems over time. This long-term data is indispensable for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development in arid and semiarid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the critical steps involved in processing and correcting cosmic ray data to derive soil moisture content in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of cosmic ray data to derive soil moisture content involves several critical steps: data screening based on voltage, relative humidity, sampling time intervals, and neutron count variability; pressure correction using the fast neutron pressure correction formula; and instrument calibration to determine N0, the fast neutron count under dry soil conditions, by comparing measured soil moisture with corrected neutron data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange collected and processed in oasis–desert ecosystems to ensure data quality and reliability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems are collected using eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations. Data processing includes data collection, processing, and archiving with quality control procedures to ensure reliable datasets, supplemented by hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are implemented to ensure the accuracy and completeness of hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure accuracy and completeness of hydrometeorological data, methodologies include using high-frequency measurements from automatic weather stations, with data averaged over 10-minute periods. Quality control involves data screening, processing, and archiving, alongside supplementary data on groundwater tables, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate collection of data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid oasis–desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: In the field above, a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems is collected. The methodologies include long-term observations using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, which involve radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and more. These methods provide a quantitative understanding of oasis–desert interactions, crucial for ecological stability and development.

Enablement.Question: How do data correction techniques enable the extraction of accurate soil moisture content from cosmic-ray neutron data in agricultural settings?
Enablement.Answer: The data correction techniques mentioned involve pressure correction of fast neutron counts and calibration to calculate soil moisture content. The process includes filtering data based on specific criteria such as atmospheric conditions and voltage levels, followed by using pressure correction formulas and soil sample calibration to determine the neutron count under dry soil conditions, which is then used to derive soil moisture content.

Enablement.Question: What resources or conditions enable the establishment of long-term observational networks in semiarid inland river basins?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of long-term observational networks in semiarid inland river basins is enabled by installing multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations, including superstations and ordinary stations. These networks, collecting data since 2012, benefit from access to water resources from the cryosphere in upper regions and comprehensive data collection covering energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, as well as auxiliary vegetation and soil parameters.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from using high-frequency hydrometeorological data for understanding long-term trends in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Given the ecological crisis of inland river basins, including the frequent occurrence of dust storms and land degradation, high-frequency data might not adequately capture long-term trends without comprehensive data processing and quality control.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to develop a comprehensive dataset that includes both natural and artificial oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: The need for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange involves complexities such as balancing oasis and desert systems for sustainable development, which requires extensive and well-coordinated data collection from both natural and artificial systems.

Judgmental.Question: How adequate are the current data collection methods in capturing the complex dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, which include long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, appear comprehensive. They utilize eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with a 10 min average period. These methods seem adequate in capturing the complex dynamics, as they incorporate a wide array of parameters, including energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and various auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in maintaining the accuracy and reliability of datasets involving oasis–desert energy and carbon flux observations?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges in maintaining accuracy and reliability include dealing with ecological environment degradation, such as river drying, vegetation degradation, intensification of land desertification, and dust storms. These environmental challenges, especially in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin and others along the Silk Road, may impact observational accuracy and data consistency.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how data collection methods in oasis–desert ecosystems account for both natural and artificial systems.
Assertion.Answer: In oasis–desert ecosystems, data collection methods involve long-term observations and datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are collected using an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations, supplemented with groundwater table data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced when collecting data on energy and water vapor exchange in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Arid regions face ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. These environmental crises complicate data collection efforts, particularly in inland river basins along the Silk Road, making it crucial to maintain long-term observation systems.
